New Records: Georgia qualified for the knockout stages of a major international tournament for the first time.
Khvicha Kvaratskhelia’s goal after 01:32 is both Georgia’s fastest ever goal scored at the UEFA European Championship and the earliest Portugal have ever conceded in the competition.
Georges Mikautadze became the first player to score or assist in each of his first three Euros outings since Gareth Bale in 2016.
Georges Mikautadze has scored in all three of Georgia’s group matches, becoming only the ninth player to score in all three group matches at a European Championship.
This was Portugal’s first competitive defeat since December 2022 and manager Roberto Martínez’s first competitive defeat in charge of Portugal.
Key Match Events: Khvicha Kvaratskhelia scored the fifth-fastest Euros goal ever at 92 seconds.
Georges Mikautadze scored a penalty early in the second half.
Luka Lochoshvili won a penalty following a challenge from António Silva.
Guram Kashia made 10 clearances, six more than anyone else on the pitch.
Pre-Game Insights: Portugal’s confirmed status as group winners led to almost wholesale changes from coach Roberto Martínez.
Cristiano Ronaldo retained his place in the lineup despite the changes.
Post-Match Reflections: Georgia coach Willy Sagnol felt comfortable enough to rest Kvaratskhelia for the final nine minutes.
This was a collective effort that produced a night Georgia won’t forget in a hurry as they became the first Euros debutants to reach the knockouts since Iceland in 2016.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Portugal saw 73% of the ball in the first 15 minutes.

João Neves, António Silva, Francisco Conceição, and Gonçalo Inácio all started for Portugal, making it the first time in their history that 4+ players under the age of 23 have started in the same match at the UEFA European Championship.
There have been four yellow cards handed out at Euro 2024 for simulation, with Portugal receiving three of those.
